metadata.case_name: Appellant (Lady Doctor) v. State of Rajasthan & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant appointed by Local Self-Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order dated 27.11.1974 as Lady Doctor under Municipal Council, Ganganagar on purely temporary basis for six months or till candidate selected by Rajasthan Public Service Commission (RPSC) is available, whichever earlier.
Appointment made under Section 308 of Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959 read with Rules 26 and 27 of Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963.
Appellant's working period continued to be extended by orders of Local Self-Government Department.
Appellant selected by RPSC in October 1976 and August 1982 but did not join pursuant to such selection.
Appellant's services terminated on 1.10.1988 on ground that candidate selected by RPSC was available.
Appellant filed writ petition No. 3739 of 1988 before Rajasthan High Court challenging termination.
Rajasthan High Court passed interim stay order on 12.10.1988 directing that appellant not to be relieved.
Interim order made absolute by Rajasthan High Court on 21.3.1989.

Learned Single Judge of Rajasthan High Court by judgment dated 5.3.1993 held termination illegal as ignoring 14 years service; directed authorities to adjudge suitability within one month and regularize services with all benefits.
State of Rajasthan filed appeal before Division Bench of Rajasthan High Court; appellant allowed to continue per interim orders.
Division Bench by judgment dated 11.4.1997 held appellant continued as temporary employee under Rule 27, no right to hold post as not selected by RPSC.
Appellant put in 28 years service: 14 years before termination and 14 years on basis of interim directions by High Court and Supreme Court.

Appellant applied for voluntary retirement nearly two years back, no final decision; given privileges under Gratuity and Pension Fund Benefit Schemes under Rajasthan Municipal Services Pension Rules, 1989.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant's termination from service is in order, particularly whether long continuance as temporary employee crystallises into enforceable right for regularization despite not being selected by RPSC.
Whether principles of legitimate expectation apply to claim permanency or regularization.

petitioner_arguments.text: Though initial appointment conditional/temporary, long period of service (28 years) assumed permanency; Single Judge justified in directing regularization.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Director, Institute of Management Development, U.P. vs. Pushpa Srivastava (1992) 4 SCC 33; Ashwani Kumar vs. State of Bihar JT 1997 (1) SC 243; Daily Rated Casual Labour vs. Union of India (1988) 1 SCC 122; Narender Chadha vs. Union of India (1986) 2 SCC 157; State of Haryana vs. Ram Diya (1990) 2 SCR 431; State of U.P. vs. Dr. Deep Narain Tripathi (1996) 8 SCC 454

petitioner_arguments.text: Benefits under Pension Rules cannot be denied; applied for voluntary retirement.

respondent_arguments.text: Appointment temporary with clear condition that service terminates if RPSC selected candidate available; appellant did not join when selected twice; no enforceable right or lien despite long service.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 27 of Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963

court_reasoning.text: Appointment under Rules 26 and 27 temporary; sub-rule (2) of Rule 27 requires reference to Commission after one year for continuance, terminated on refusal; no automatic extension or presumption of concurrence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No scope for regularization without regular appointment by RPSC selection.

court_reasoning.text: Even for temporary appointment, selection irrelevant; extensions do not imply Commission's concurrence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Currency of appointment lost after one year without reference.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents distinguished as different factual backgrounds; no general rule for regularization of ad-hoc/temporary based on long service.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ad-hoc appointee replaced only by regularly selected candidate.

court_reasoning.text: Principle of legitimate expectation not applicable; no representation or waiver shown; mere continuance does not create impression of waived conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legitimate expectation requires clear representation, reliance, detriment; overridden by public interest and rules.

holdings.text: Temporary appointment under Rule 27 does not confer right to hold post or regularization without RPSC selection; termination valid as RPSC candidate available.
No legitimate expectation for continuance or regularization.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Division Bench judgment; termination valid, no regularization or right to post as temporary appointee without RPSC selection; no legitimate expectation; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The only point involved in this appeal is whether the appellants termination from service is in order.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: No appointment made under sub-rule (1) shall be continued beyond a period of one year without referring it to the Commission for their concurrence and shall be terminated immediately on their refusal to concur.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key rule interpretation defeating regularization claim.

key_quotes.text: Unless the initial recruitment is regularized through a prescribed agency, there is no scope for a demand for regularization.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.
key_quotes.speaker: court
